^45111496^172^65^"Learned the hard way that the $45 plan I choose was more than I needed. Very rarely use the call side of the plan. Use 99% of the time for texts. SO I bought a $30 plan - found that I am NOT allowed to change the plan. ST added the $30 plan and I lost a week of service.

column1: To explain - $45.00 bought 30 days of full service. Tried to change the plan - they added the card and I got only 21 days of full service. I was told that I would have to purchase a totally new ST service and change the number in order to have a $30.. plan.
Voice mail recordings are always static and are not always clear.
Customer service is poor. I have called in a few times for help. When the rep is done with the task they have just hung up. This caused me to have to call back
column2: hold through the queue and then ask for help again for the other questions I needed hello with.

column1: When you want to add a pre-paid card in reserve - you must call or chat in.
I need a second phone for my crafting business - I defiantly will NOT be buying that service with Straight Talk."^2^December 8

column2: ^45111496^162^27^"I have been a Straight Talk customer for several years & have been fairly satisfied with them. In October 2014 I bought a Samsung Galaxy S4. I was offered the 'Easy Exchange' warranty program & I bought it. January 14th 2016 my phone failed. I reported the phone was broke & they sent me a prepaid FedEx envelope which took about four days to get. I also had to pay a $49.00 deductible. I sent the phone back as instructed. It is now February 1st & I still don't have a replacement phone. Not only do I not have a phone
column3: Straight Talk isn't sure when my replacement phone will be shipped. I have been without a phone for over two weeks with no real idea of when I will get a phone. THE 'EASY EXCHANGE' PROGRAM IS A JOKE. Once I get a new phone I will be dropping Straight Talk & going with a carrier that will let me bring my own phone."^1^February 1

column2: ^45111496^133^11^"I love the Straight Talk plan so I would have given it 5 stars
column3: but buying it on line would have been a huge irritation if I hadn't already read the other reviews that said this same thing: THERE ARE NO INSTRUCTIONS THAT TELL YOU TO PRINT YOUR ORDER TO GET THE PIN!!!!!!! That is so stupid. You buy it on line
column4: wait about an hour and then they send you your digital purchase by email. What they do not tell you is that you have to now print it out to get the actual PIN number that you need. You do not get it in the email like you would assume so if you are not by a printer it is pointless to buy it on line. Other than that it was great."^3^June 6

column2: ^45111496^70^12^"This company used to have a better deal than any of the other carriers
column3: until recently. They decided to stop giving $5 off for auto-refill and only give $1 now. Their $45 plan now comes out to almost $50 after taxes
column4: and that's with auto-pay! I remember when the $45 plan used to be a little over $46 with taxes and auto-pay.  Another drawback to this company that I just found out tonight
column5: is if you want to jump ship and take your number with you to another company
column6: your new cell phone carrier pretty much has to plead and negotiate with Straight Talk to let them have your number !  My new carrier spent most of this evening trying to get Straight Talk to give up my number so that it can be ported.  Here it is 3 hrs later and Straight Talk still hasn't held their end of the bargain! My new carrier also let me in on that Straight Talk has a history of doing this to customers that want to discontinue service with them. My suggestion to anyone wanting to try this company
column7: you can do better!

column1: -There are companies that have hot spots and you can tether your phone to use it. Straight Talk doesn't let you tether your phone.

column2: for $50 you at least 8 gb of data with some other cell phone carriers
column3: whereas it's $49 with taxes for Straight Talk's $45 plan and you only get 5 gb of data."^1^December 2

column2: ^45111496^59^19^"Straight Talk's service is good. I've only had a few minor problems. The biggest was when I was driving through South Dakota and my phone went off completely and it took nearly two hours to talk to someone who knew how to fix it. I've also ordered a refurbished phone from them on the straight talk site (much cheaper than on here from what I've seen). I had to buy an extra month of minutes though - even though I've been a customer for years and am enrolled in the auto-renew program. The package was delivered via FedEx 3-day shipping that took over a week to get because Straight Talk put the wrong address on the box. The ordeal of explaining how I even figured that out would take too long to write. After I finally got it
column3: the phone was in a big box with one medium sized bag of air
column4: with the smaller box the phone was in bouncing around. If you never had to deal with straight talk you are blessed. Their service isn't bad though (from my experience)."^1^March 14

column2: ^45111496^55^14^"Customer service is absolutely horrible. They read from a script and just repeat everything until you want to give up and end the call. I would NOT recommend Straight talk to anyone unless you have no other option. Reading through reviews
column3: this is a common occurrence and they obviously don't care how horrible their customer service is.

column1: Just know when you sign up with Straight talk you will NOT be happy with the customer service if you ever run into an issue and you will most likely end your conversation with them and not be happy with the outcome either."^1^November 16

column2: ^45111496^55^2^"Walmart should include some instructions on how to use this e-card. It only took me about an hour to figure out you have to 'print' it to see the pin number."^5^March 18

^45111496^53^12^"We've been using Straight Talk for years now and I have never been more frustrated with them until this situation occurred. We were on the last day of our service and both our phones are on the same days of service. My phone was still working and as far as we were aware so was my SO's but it had died so we just refilled them as usual. However
column3: in the time my SO's phone was dead
column4: they deactivated it a gave away his phone number. It had only been HOURS maybe that it was deactivated and they gave away the phone number he had been using for years! This is only double frustrating as he's also got job app he just sent out with his 'old' phone number because they just effing give away your phone number the second your phone deactivates apparently. I'm holding back my swearing but I'm absolutely livid about this. That is so ridiculous. I will be switching phone carriers because of this and will never recommend StraightTalk to anyone. Their customer service has been a nightmare too
column5: every time we've had to deal with them through the years. I'm just done and that was the straw that broke the camel's back!"^1^February 19

column2: ^45111496^52^13^"I got so tired of paying ridiculous money for spotty or nonexistent service and decided to switch to straight talk after hearing from others how great it worked. I now get much better service and the same unlimited options I had before for a fraction of the cost and I couldn't be happier. I have travelled across the country this summer and had no problems with signal. You do have to remember to load a new calling card to your account every month but you get reminders well in advance. I found that it is a few dollars cheaper to buy them in store rather than the auto delivery on Straight Talks website even though  that is more convenient. Great service for far less money - a no brainer."^5^August 18

^45111496^49^6^"I had been on auto refill . My debit card got compromised. I called in ahead of time and told them my new card number.  They started me over as a new auto refill customer. I called and explain to them and they didn't change it back. I Canceled and currently looking for another plan."^2^November 13

column6: even though it just sits there 'sending' for a few minutes and then i have to 'retry' after that.  hopefully after this months bill is up

column2: ^45111496^44^7^"Love the service

^45111496^16^7^"I've been a faithful customer of straighttalk for the past seven years.  I've had two lines personally and also purchased lines for my parents.  That's a total of 4 lines for 7 years.  The customer service was absolutely appalling.  Tracfone/straighttalk seem to not care about their longstanding customers.  I finally had enough and decided to switch to AT&T's prepaid service which I should've done sooner.

column1: My straight talk service utilized the AT&T network so it only made sense for me to switch to AT&T's prepaid option.  My straighttalk plan ended on 8/13 at midnight and that morning I attempted to port my number to AT&T however Straighttalk wouldn't release my number to AT&T.  I was forced to purchase another $45 plan in order to reactivate my number so it could be transferred.  Once transferred
column2: I lost the minutes which was a complete loss.

column1: The customer service was absolute garbage.  I sent an email to the corporate office of tracfone (since they don't offer a phone number) and didn't receive a response for 2 weeks.
AT&T offers 2GB less of data however
column2: with auto refill you save $5 per month on your bill. Also
column3: with their mult-line discount
column4: you receive an additional $5 savings on subsequent lines.  All in all

column1: HERE'S HOW TO KEEP YOUR PHONE NUMBER
A lot of people gripe about losing their phone number when they reactivate their phone
column2: but the trick is
column3: if your service has been disconnected because you didn't add air time right away
column4: all you do is select the add airtime option and your service comes back on with the same number.  If you decide to reactivate
column5: it activates it with a new number.  I've gone as long as a week with no service and still had the same phone number because I simply added the airtime as if my service hadn't run out.  In fact
column6: most of the time I forget and end up going about a day before realizing my phone is out of airtime.  I've had the same number for 5 years now (would be longer
column7: but I chose to change it)."^5^April 25

^45111496^1^1^"We have been on straight talk for years. Even talked several of our friends and relatives to switch to straight talk. Never had any problems with the service but the customer service is awful. I got a new straight talk iPhone 6 about 6 months ago and gave my old straight talk 5s to my sister in law at that time and helped set up her service. I ordered a new SIM card for it. When we got it in the mail we called and told them she wanted her old number transferred and they ended up giving her a new number by mistake. Even though it was their mistake they said that we would have to get a new SIM card and they would have to send it because wasn't available in the store.  Took about 5 days to straighten it out with the new sim. A few weeks ago my brother in law gave me his old iPhone 7 and I got on line to transfer my number to it. Tried to call my sister in law in the mean time and got a recording of no service. I finally figured out they transferred my sister in laws number to my new phone.  Her phone quit working and she is home bound and and was getting home health. I thought it would be an easy fix
column3: but no. They said since her phone was a straight talk phone I had to get a new SIM card for her and they would have to send it and it ended up taking about 6 days to get it. I had to drive 30 miles to take her my phone so she would have one. Then I had to go back when I got the SIM card to fix her phone. That finally taken care of I transferred my number to the new phone by calling them. They ended up stopping my auto refill for no reason. I have been on the phone with them a lot lately. They are all overseas and most of them you have trouble understanding and they have trouble understanding you.  I tried to call their corporate headquarters to let them know about my problems so they could improve their service to no avail. I was routed all over the world about 10 times to overseas countries
column4: everywhere except their headquarters in supposedly
column5: Florida. I finally gave up. I really don't think it exists."^1^December 20

column2: ^947596782^1^0^"So I've been an android fan/user for the past 3 years but I recently purchased a macbook and ipad and liked them so much I decided to give the iphone a try
column3: but didn't want to splurge on one of the later models until I was sure I was comfortable using ios. Well I've had the phone for about 2 weeks now and I can honestly say I probably will never go back to android.

column1: The phone is in fact BRAND NEW
column2: comes sealed with instruction booklet
column3: headphones and charger
column4: as well as a sim card (the sim card slot opener is underneath the phone holder in the box in an envelope
column5: use that and not a paperclip).  If you already have an apple id account setting up is a breeze. I was able to transfer over most of my apps from my android using the Move to IOS app on my Samsung phone. If you have straight talk your service will now be under tracfone but you still pay through straight talk and buy straight talk monthly plans.

column1: The 32 GB of space is more than enough
column2: I didn't transfer the 2
column3: 000 photos I had on my camera roll from my old phone
column4: instead I uploaded them to google photos on my old phone
column5: then downloaded the google photos app on my iphone and chose which photos I wanted to transfer to my phone. I was initially worried about not having expandable memory like I did on my other androids
column6: but after installing all of my apps and downloading my itunes library
column7: I still have about 14GB of storage left

column1: The camera is probably one of my favorite features. Coming from an 8MP phone and going to a 12MP phone
column2: was a huge deal to me. I take lots of photos for work so having a good camera is a must. I like the live photo feature that allows me to take photos and takes like a 3 second video with each one. The screen is very nice and vibrant I also love the touch ID feature
column3: I no longer have to use my password on certain secure apps on my phone. I also like the fact this phone comes with a headphone jack
column4: unlike the 7
column5: 8 or X  series. Syncing my iphone to my macbook and ipad is another great feature. With icloud
column6: I can take a picture with my phone and have them automatically show up on my macbook and ipad. I also enabled the sync over wifi that way I can sync my itunes library to my iphone without using an USB cord

column2: for the price this phone is a steal. I know it's almost 5 years old but I think if you'd like to try out an Iphone without breaking the bank this phone is perfect.

column1: *I suggest getting the square trade 2 year warranty. For $50 you get a piece of mind that if you drop your phone
column2: spill a drink or have mechanical failure
column3: you don't have to pay out of pocket. There is a $29 deductible but I find that very reasonable considering the cost to fix any issue with your phone will cost AT LEAST $50."^5^March 19

^45111503^21^4^"I've been using straight talk $45/month plan for about 2 years now and it's the best phone plan I've ever had.  I have used it with iphones and Android.  It uses the at&t network

column4: but after that you don't need to adjust anything.  Just make sure you track your data consumption and don't go over 5 gigs in your 30 day billing period or you will get throttled to a very slow data speeds.  There are a few downsides.  You can't use straight talk in other countries
column5: even Canada or Mexico.  Customer service is horrible if you ever need it.  A Google search works better than calling straight talk.  It does take a few minutes to set up the data settings on your phone.  I've had problems not getting picture text messages
column6: but not anymore.  Maybe they fixed it.  Overall it's a great service and you will save a lot over Verizon and AT&T."^5^November 20

^29749071^203^34^"$15 bucks for 1 gig does not seem like a good deal at first. It is basically mostly an activation fee. It keeps the device active and you get 1 gig of data for those who only need the mobile hotspot once in a while. Sure beats what the others charge for a basic low data plan. They charge 50 bucks for 5 gigs whether or not you need 5 gigs a month or not. At least I can keep my service active and if I need more data in a month I simply buy a larger data plan card. It is not for the heavy user. Of course the larger amount of data you buy that month each gig gets cheaper. As you are not paying for the initial activation fee and buying in bulk they can charge less per gig too. For me it is a great deal as in most months I don't even use the whole amount. $15 bucks for backup internet is well worth it. It means if the power and DSL are knocked out and I have important things like business to tend to online I am not out more money by losing a sale or an order I made get screwed up by the outage. If its stormy I just switch off the DSL and hop on the hotspot and stuff gets done"^5^March 20

^480000580^3^0^"Upgrading from the S8 which is a great phone in of itself. It's lighting fast.  I just installed USB 3.1 ports on my desktop computer and i literally transferred 450 mb of photos that i had originally transferred from my old phone at least twice as fast as i would have before.  Seemingly transferred in the blink of an eye.  The prism blue is just a stunning color. After having the phone a few days now
column3: I can  now say with confidence.  The messaging is much faster and has a few nicer more intuitive features (using Message + with Verizon). Snappier response times from all apps and functions overall.  I'm a sound engineer by trade
column4: so I love making my own ringtones and they upload with ease to the S10 + and play beautifully through its Dolby Atmos speakers.  I have extensive LED lighting throughout my home and control all of it through Amazon Alexa which works seamlessly with the S10+ . I use my spottily premium account to listen to my playlists in my Honda CRV which also paired  via Bluetooth with the S10+ with out even a slight hiccup The camera is a very clear

column2: ^702494549^1^0^"So I've been an android fan/user for the past 3 years but I recently purchased a macbook and ipad and liked them so much I decided to give the iphone a try
column3: but didn't want to splurge on one of the later models until I was sure I was comfortable using ios. Well I've had the phone for about 2 weeks now and I can honestly say I probably will never go back to android.

column1: The phone is in fact BRAND NEW
column2: comes sealed with instruction booklet
column3: headphones and charger
column4: as well as a sim card (the sim card slot opener is underneath the phone holder in the box in an envelope
column5: use that and not a paperclip).  If you already have an apple id account setting up is a breeze. I was able to transfer over most of my apps from my android using the Move to IOS app on my Samsung phone. If you have straight talk your service will now be under tracfone but you still pay through straight talk and buy straight talk monthly plans.

column1: The 32 GB of space is more than enough
column2: I didn't transfer the 2
column3: 000 photos I had on my camera roll from my old phone
column4: instead I uploaded them to google photos on my old phone
column5: then downloaded the google photos app on my iphone and chose which photos I wanted to transfer to my phone. I was initially worried about not having expandable memory like I did on my other androids
column6: but after installing all of my apps and downloading my itunes library
column7: I still have about 14GB of storage left

column1: The camera is probably one of my favorite features. Coming from an 8MP phone and going to a 12MP phone
column2: was a huge deal to me. I take lots of photos for work so having a good camera is a must. I like the live photo feature that allows me to take photos and takes like a 3 second video with each one. The screen is very nice and vibrant I also love the touch ID feature
column3: I no longer have to use my password on certain secure apps on my phone. I also like the fact this phone comes with a headphone jack
column4: unlike the 7
column5: 8 or X  series. Syncing my iphone to my macbook and ipad is another great feature. With icloud
column6: I can take a picture with my phone and have them automatically show up on my macbook and ipad. I also enabled the sync over wifi that way I can sync my itunes library to my iphone without using an USB cord

column2: for the price this phone is a steal. I know it's almost 5 years old but I think if you'd like to try out an Iphone without breaking the bank this phone is perfect.

column1: *I suggest getting the square trade 2 year warranty. For $50 you get a piece of mind that if you drop your phone
column2: spill a drink or have mechanical failure
column3: you don't have to pay out of pocket. There is a $29 deductible but I find that very reasonable considering the cost to fix any issue with your phone will cost AT LEAST $50."^5^March 19

^381147781^1^0^"I've had a Note 4 since early 2015 and it's got to where it has to be charged at least twice a day even with a new battery. A local Wal-Mart store had a Stylo 4 on display and the big screen jumped out at me. Upon further examination I saw it had a stylus which was a huge plus. At $199.99 the price was right because even if I just get a year of good use out of it I won't feel ripped off. The store didn't have it in stock so I ordered it online and picked it up a few days later. Setup was easy
column3: within 10 minutes I had all my info changed over from my Note. The screen is nice and bright but where this phone shines for me is battery life. I got the phone on Monday and charged it full that night. Nearly 48 hours later I still have 46% battery left so it will have made it 2 full days one a single charge. People complain about the RAM and all that but the phone is faster than my Samsung with much better battery life. So if you want a phone with a big screen and great battery life without spending a thousand dollars definitely think about this phone."^5^September 12

^51255172^1^0^"We needed a flip phone for my partially blind 85-year-old mother. She confuses easily and so it had to be simple and easy to see and feel. I carefully investigated and chose GreatCall Jitterbug Flip as our best option. We ordered an extra charging cradle
column3: one for night (bedside) and one for day so the cellphone could remain fully charged and easy to reach. We also subscribed to the 5Star service and have two automatic daily wellness calls.

column1: I carefully set up the phone and we immediately started having problems.
- The charging cradle is badly designed
column2: don't use it. We have two cradles and they both have the exact same problems:
if you just casually set the flip phone into the cradle
column3: the odds are that the contacts won't be properly aligned and the phone won't be connected to the battery charger circuit. The phone must be slightly leaning backwards to seat properly
column4: if it's leaning too far back or if you set it into the cradle vertically
column5: the contacts don't align. We even tried to shim the dock opening with no success.  A good design would ensure that the contacts connect reliably to the cellphone every time one is docked.

column2: you don't get a reliable connection between the cable and the micro USB jack in the back. I accidentally wiggled it and discovered the cable wasn't making a good connection
column3: despite being plugged in completely. I even went to the trouble of applying hot-glue around the micro-USB plug to securely attach it to the cradle. Even with the hot glue
column4: wiggling or bending the cable STILL caused the connection to occasionally fail. The problem is clearly the charger base jacks
column5: not the cables.

column2: there should be no plugs or loose cables. Using a USB cable is cheap and downright mean
column3: and it endangers these users. The wall power module should have a long
column4: permanent cable and the connection to the charging cradle should also be permanent or have a mechanical lock requiring a deliberate effort to unplug the cable from the base. The plug should obviously be USB-C which is reversible
column5: not the older mini-USB
column6: or the mechanical lock should clearly allow the cable to only be inserted into the charging base with the proper orientation. It's far too easy to unplug the standard cable and I've already commented on how unreliable the cable-jack connection is on the back of the charging cradle.

column1: - It should be possible under 'Settings' to disable the volume control buttons to prevent a user from accidentally turning the ringer down or completely off (vibrate only).  Time after time I have found our cellphone with the ringer volume off
column2: and of course Mom didn't hear any calls. I ended up using a Dremel tool to grind down the Volume Down button
column3: it now takes a pointed object to deliberately press it
column4: no more 'accidents'.

column1: - You should be able to clear the Call History and more information should be displayed under 'Phone Info'
- I just realized that it's not possible to take photos
column2: instead of a standard camera feature the Magnify feature has potential but the image clarity and focus are terrible."^4^August 5

^51255172^1^0^"I ordered this phone for my mother but there was nothing on the website to indicate that service for this phone is not available in all areas.  She lives in rural KY and was told that it could not be activated there."^1^March 12
^51255172^1^0^"After getting tired of logging the big smartphone and dropping it
column3: not hearing it ring because it was too big for my pockets

column5: finally simplified my life again

^54188796^43^4^"The manufacturer's number on the Walmart website indicated it was the unlocked version sold by Apple.  I decided to take a chance since I could return it promptly if not as described.  I needed an unlocked or locked to T-Mobile phone.

column1: I had the phone shipped to a local store and opened the box with the clerk present.  Phone was in an original Apple box and shrink wrapped.  It was as new
column2: including all accessories--no signs of usage.   The only way to tell it wasn't brand new was the plastic screen protector had bubbles under it.

column1: I popped my T-Mobile SIM card in
column2: happily went to set up
column3: and was disappointed--phone clearly not recognizing the SIM card.  I called T-Mobile--they said they thought the phone was locked to Family Mobile--I call them
column4: and they said they'd happily unlock the phone after several months of service.  Not an option
column5: think he phone's going back....disappointed....

column1: I decide to research the phone on the Apple website--no info about carrier lock
column2: but

column1: learn it has Apple warranty through September 2017.  I decided to call the local Apple Store
column2: while on hold
column3: I decide to plug the IMEI number into the major carrier's online activation checks.  I hit paydirt first try as AT&T said it could be activated!  I immediately went to their unlock page and learned I simply had to fill out a request form to have the phone unlocked.  About that time Apple answered the phone and confirmed it was an AT&T phone
column4: and that I likely just had to request the unlock.  I immediately did so
column5: received a confirmation email saying it could be up to 2 days for processing.  I went to log in to my iTunes account to see if there was anything else I could do to speed process
column6: and an email popped up saying my phone was unlocked--5 mins to process request--was I happy!

column1: I restarted the phone with my T-Mobile SIM installed
column2: and immediately had T-Mobile service!!!!
yes
column3: I'd recommend taking the chance.  If by chance the Apple warranty wasn't good
column4: there is a 60 day warranty offered by the refurbishing company.  This was indicated by a business card placed in the shipping box--almost missed it
column5: so look for it.

column1: I hope this review is  of help to other shoppers."^5^April 12

column2: ^123752690^1^0^"The phone was defective and the instructions were unclear. I'm sending it  back. Your staff was excellent

column9: it is a VERY big one in my book and is why I can't give this phone a full 5 star rating. You can't remove the battery! ^271853560^1^0^"I bought this phone because I really needed to upgrade. My previous phone was a $50 Samsung that just wasn't making the cut. I decided to buy this phone because I've owned a couple of Motorola phones in the past and I really liked them. For a $100 phone

I have gotten the 'not responding' pop up once or twice in those apps
column4: but that's it.  My favorite thing about this phone so far
column5: is how durable it is. This evening I sat the phone down on one of my basement steps as I was taking some bags of trash downstairs. I accidentally knocked the phone off of the edge of the step and it fell about 6 feet down and landed on a concrete floor. I was so sure that I had just killed my phone. But
column6: when I picked it up
column7: it didn't have a scratch on it and it worked perfectly. I've had phones that were 3 or 4 times more expensive than this one that broke after falling only 1-2 feet from the ground. I would definitely recommend this phone to anyone that is looking for a more budget friendly phone."^5^May 9

column3: I downgraded from a Droid Turbo to this phone
column4: because I felt like my smartphone had taken over my life. Anyways
column5: I got this because it was $10 and it worked with Family Mobile
column6: Walmart's cell service. Honestly
column7: I wasn't expecting much. Thought I could get this until I found something better. But
column8: I am blown away by the amount of features this phone offers for only $10. Aside from not having a QWERTY keyboard
column9: this phone has everything else I need. I don't want access to the internet or apps on my phone anymore
column10: but I would still like to have access if I really need it. This phone has a browser that displays pages just like a laptop or smartphone
column11: except that the page is ultra magnified to make up for the low resolution. Otherwise
column12: I was able to check if I had any new Yahoo Mail messages and was able to do a Google search. I'm really surprised to find out it has Bluetooth. I'm even more surprised to find out it has a micro SD slot up to 32 GB's. Looking forward to using it as an mp3 player. Probably the most amazing thing
column13: for a $10 phone
column14: is that it has speech recognition. Haven't tried it yet
column15: cuz I never really liked that feature on my Droid Turbo. But
column16: I'm kinda shocked that a $10 phone can have all these higher end features. The battery is pretty decent and charges up really fast. So

column2: ^53970798^14^20^"The Verizon Moto G4 Play is a bit of a throwback with its thick metal band sides and deceptive size that in the end contain a small 5 inch screen.

column1: The Marshmallow operating system is what really saves the day with a lot of added and time saving features over Lollipop.
Durability is only fair as the old style wrap around frame is subject to denting and therefore cracking the screen which is made of gen 3 Gorilla glass.
Non slippy back is a good feature but in the end you will likely want to get rubberized impact protection.
Annoying features are its oversized for its small screen
column2: the screen is for some reason a dust magnet while battery live is poor and charge time even when completely turned off....it recharges VERY slow.

column1: Where it shines it phone sound quality and the ability to work well even with just one bar signal strength.
Also it has a very good camera which is a plus but somewhat odd considering.
Online performance is good IF you avoid the Opera browsers which really put a drag on internet performance
column2: best browser for data saving and speed is the UC browser.

column1: Overall for what it is it is a $29.00 phone at best so it is all about how bad you want it and wether or not you are using rose colored glasses.
This phone reluctantly replaces my favorite LG Premier because Verizon doesn't support it
column2: but moving to the Moto from the Premier is like going from a BMW to a Fiat."^3^April 8

column2: ^53970798^10^0^"I don't know who is subsidizing this phone
column3: but this phone is a steal. You are getting a frustration free experience for less than the fraction of price of a decent tablet with the same specs.

column1: I've had it for only a few hours and here are the few things it lacks and what I love about it.
It lacks an LED indicator to let you know if it is charging/charged/message. This means I have to turn my screen on to see if my phone is fully charged or if I have a message waiting.
I can't figure out how to get my battery% value next to the clock... I guess Moto turned off this Android feature.
16GB storage Ram and 2GB working RAM! I haven't experienced any lag. 2GB working RAM is a must have these days.
Built in FM radio. Maybe it's listed somewhere in the specs
column2: but I missed this feature that belongs in every phone. No more tearing up my data plan just to enjoy some local radio.

column1: This phone came with a huge battery that I haven't seen since a much larger phone. This battery takes up almost 2/3rds of the phone. I haven't tested longevity yet.
Colorful options for the back! What?! I opened the box and these fell out as I was opening it up from the back. The other two colors are blue and lavender/purple.
The camera in my less than ideal living room lighting late at night is very responsive on the main 8M side. It has true HDR capabilities. What's not to love with true HD?
For the selfies... the chat camera is equally responsive in bright light
column2: and smart enough to use the screen as an off white flash to provide a good photo in poor lighting when the room is too dark for a good photo. This was the only time the camera delayed.

column1: Adaptive brightness... not all cheap phones have this feature. This one does. When it's dark
column2: the screen dims so you aren't staring at a harshly bright screen.

column1: Emergency Alerts. The last couple phones I've had lacked this feature and I missed it. Glad to see this available. We'll see how well this is implemented since my last network was not Verizon and I can't remember the last time I got an emergency alert.
Like I said before. I can't believe I paid less than $50 for these specs!
Here's a heads up... you do need to do firmware updates for security purposes. If the phone doesn't prompt you
column2: you can do it yourself from Settings - About Phone - System Updates. At the time of this review 7/31/17) there were three separate updates. The third update required access to WiFi. Allocate about 10-15 minutes for each update.

column1: Firmware updates are not a bad thing. It's actually reassuring to see that Motorola is maintaining an up to date firmware for this phone."^5^July 31

^953073971^16^11^"Bought this very same phone for my wife from Amazon for $99. They sold it unlocked & we set it up with Republic Wireless. Republic had the cheapest prepaid plan: $20 for 1GB wireless data + unlimited calls/text [on the T-Mobile network] + unlimited data when using your wireless network at home [or any wifi network anywhere]. It was our 1st smartphone and she couldn't be happier to finally upgrade from her old flip phone. So then I bought this phone from Walmart for $40
column3: to replace my old flip phone. It is the same phone as my wife's
column4: only it is locked to Verizon.

column1: We had an old Verizon family plan for our flip phones that cost us $85/month. My wife's phone came with a new phone #. When I got this Verizon-locked phone from Walmart I did NOT activate it as the instructions wanted me to do. I just put in the battery. Then I called Verizon and told them I wanted to make a change to our family plan.
Told them I wanted to keep one of the phone #s on that plan
column2: and use it on a new prepaid Verizon plan. I wanted the other # on the family plan to be ported to another carrier [Republic Wireless].

column1: Since I hadn't done anything on this new Verizon-locked Walmart-bought phone [other than put in the battery]
column2: the Verizon rep handled EVERYTHING for me on the phone. In less than 10 minutes the rep had my new phone up & running
column3: keeping the same phone # I had
column4: and taking the first payment of $40 for my new Verizon prepaid plan [3GB/month of wireless data + unlimited calls/text + unlimited wifi data].

column1: We then googled up the Republic Wireless website to port over my wife's existing phone # she has with Verizon. It was really easy to do [the only problem was Republic doesn't want you to enter the 'dash' character that is part of the Verizon account #. It failed until we realized 'hey
column2: let's try NOT putting in the 'dash' and VOILA! It accepted it our request to port my wife's #].

column1: In less than 24 hours from having walked out of Walmart with this phone
column2: my wife and I each now have this moto e4 phone and they both have the same phone numbers we previously had.

column1: If Republic Wireless service proves to be ok
column2: I plan on switching this Verizon-locked moto e4 over to Republic. Many people have done this; this moto e4 CAN work on any network
column3: it's just that this Verizon-locked version of it has had all the other networks disabled. To enable it to work on other networks
column4: people just get an unlock code
column5: easily bought on ebay for $2. [You also would need to buy a sim card for another network].

column1: So our $85/month flip-phone family-plan is now gone. Verizon sent a confirming email to us that the account is deactivated now that there no longer are any phones on it. Woo hoo!
$42/month for this moto e4 + $20/month for my wife's Republic moto e4 = $23 less than I had been paying for flip-phone-only service. Woo hoo again!
In a month I expect to save another $19/month when I unlock this Verizon-locked moto e4 & switch it over to Republic. WOO HOO!"^5^October 4

column2: ^953073971^16^4^"I'm a Samsung person but when my phone broke

Lots of settings to deal with that were different from my previous phones. Less bloatware on this phone which is a huge plus. Can't beat the price. Of course it's not going to do all that a high end (and high priced) phone will do but it does everything I want it to do."^5^October 2

column2: ^953073971^12^3^"I have 5 of these phones! (4 Verizon pre-paid versions and 1 unlocked version directly from Motorola) I had originally heard about this phone on Amazon. There was a lengthy review from a guy who's had at least 25 or more Android phones in his life and he raved about this phone. I was going to get the flagship OnePlus phone but he convinced me to give this one a try. The only question
column3: since this is a locked phone
column4: was whether or not it would work with a GSM carrier like AT&T. The answer: It DOES work on GSM carriers (Verizon is a CDMA carrier
column5: which is different. But the phone can handle both.)

column1: I originally ordered the unlocked version directly from Motorola
column2: but it got hung up in some weird customs paperwork red tape so I decided to run up to Walmart
column3: buy the locked Verizon version
column4: and see if it worked (with an unlock code readily available on eBay for around $2). It worked like a charm
column5: so while they had my 'real' E4 tied up in customs for a week
column6: I started using this $40 version in its place. I liked it so much I ran up and got another Verizon $40 phone (+ $2.20 for the unlock code) before I ever received my 'real' E4.

column2: I actually prefer the pre-paid version to the 'real' version. It has some nice built-in features (like the ability to click a box and get a numerical percentage of the remaining battery life without having to install a separate app) and the updates are more regular with the Verizon version than with the Motorola version. This phone is quick
column3: bright
column4: has great battery life (AND a replaceable battery!) and has a lot of nice features
column5: like a fingerprint scanner that actually works. Personally
column6: I prefer its 5' size to the larger 5.5' size of the E4 Plus. And you just can't beat the price.

column1: I did do one thing that really made this phone a grand slam
column2: because the internal 16GB of memory is a little inadequate. I activated the 'Developer Options' hidden feature (Google to find out how to do that) and afterwards selected the 'Force allow apps on external' option from within the 'Developer Options' section. This is critical to allow an added memory card to absorb some app data. Without this option
column3: the internal memory will eventually get overloaded; WITH this option
column4: the phone is perfect. NOTE: This approach is different than formatting the memory card as 'Internal' (vs portable). That option
column5: available after Android 5
column6: is a nightmare. This option basically does the same thing but without all the headaches associated with formatting the memory card as 'Internal'. (Google that if you want a whole list of the problems encountered.)

column2: without a doubt
column3: the best phone on the planet for the price. In fact
column4: it's better than a lot of phones costing 10 times as much."^5^November 23

column2: ^953073971^8^12^"I was amazed at the features this phone has

column2: ^953073971^7^52^"Okay I read stupendous reviews about this phone which is why I decided to give it a try. Here are the things that I have yet to read after reading 75 reviews and here's the deal everyone who writes these reviews says essentially the same thing it's like the sheeple are making the reviews so here are the things about the phone that I found good. First let's put things in perspective I never pay more than 30 or 40 bucks a phone. Coming from that this phone is fast it's got beautiful screen visual colors and it has a pretty good camera better than 0.3 front-facing I'm used to okay now let me tell you what absolutely sucks about this phone. The caller log I've had 30 phones over the last 20 years and all of them have had when you hit your phone a call log is somewhere that you can just tap it and look at it I'm talking all your calls calls you make calls that are coming in cause you missed it's in one line this phone oh no you hate your phone and immediately your son to a it automatically applies favorites to random contacts you've entered so you just going to throw you into a favorite box then you have to scroll to your history and it's going to show you a scaled-down history from there you have to go up to the top right-hand screen hit the three dots hit call history then you can see your call history and then only the calls you taken you have to slide the screen over to see cause you've missed. I realize a lot of people do not talk on the phone so if you don't talk on the phone this is a non-issue I spend a lot of time on the phone I do a lot of business on the phone. There is no reason why I should spend more than one or two tops looking for my call log this is like a six-step 7-step process just to see what calls you've missed
column3: ridiculous. The next issue is there's no way to change the colors of your phone you get to gray or orange orange is battery saving grace is normal next no way to hide your Caller ID if you wanted to for there's no audio recorder so you have to install one there's also New Media Player so when you record a video you have to go to your photos which is stored online and the use Google photos to player video. I can go on and on about how I've spent six hours trying to work around the fundamental basics That are missing from this phone"^3^November 8

column4: I daily drive this phone and I haven't had the need to look at something in the flagship lineup at all since I got it.  had the g6 play prior to this and I like the 4000mah battery in that one as well both awesome mid-tier devices for a budget-minded power user that still doesn't want to sacrifice the high end feel and look.  excuse my grammar and punctuation. late night quick review don't feel like being picky about it."^4^January 25

column2: ^49053850^45^17^"The iPhone six has offered many improvements since the last generation of iPhones. I have owned an iPhone 6 for roughly a year
column3: and you will be thoroughly impressed with the way Apple has improved the features rather than just solely introducing new features.

column1: The first feature that will catch your eye is the fingerprint scanner in the home button. The way Apple has seemingly perfected this feature will make you never want to give it up
column2: because of how convenient it is.

column1: The second improvement is the larger screen and a sleek thinning design. Although the increase of screen size creates somewhat of an inconvenience in storage it makes your streaming
column2: gaming or typing much easier. If you game you will enjoy the extra space on the screen when using a d-pad.

column1: There has also been a pretty substantial improvement to the battery life of the iPhone 6 model compared to the earlier iPhone 5 models. You are able to talk on the phone for four to six more hours depending on the model of iPhone 5 you are comparing to. Also
column2: you will be able to enjoy nearly ten extra hours of audio playback.

column1: The iPhone 6 is much more reliable compared to that of my previous iPhone 5s. The amount of crashes has been pretty minimal in comparison.  After a year of use I can count the amount of crashes on one hand. The lack of crashes will make the use of the iPhone 6 less stressful for you in comparison to earlier models.
The last improvement we are going to discuss
column2: and one of the main selling points for all iPhones
column3: is the camera quality. I am not a very frequent picture taker
column4: but there has been a good improvement to the quality due to the improvement to stabilization.

column1: Overall the iPhone 6 has many improvements that are a big step in the right direction for Apple. The list of improvements to the iPhone 6 is pretty long
column2: but the battery life
column3: reliability and fingerprint scanner will have you loving the iPhone 6. I would recommend the iPhone 6 if you are looking for a user-friendly phone
column4: love high quality pictures
column5: or are a fan of Apple products."^4^September 23

column2: ^49230903^2^0^"I was skeptical when I first thought of buying an Apple IPHONE from Walmart
column3: but I read the reviews and that put my mind at ease.  So I decided to try it for myself.  I wanted to pay less money
column4: and I wanted a phone that was GSM capable and unlocked.  My current service is with Verizon Wireless and I was not even sure if the phone would work with their current service/system.  I wanted a GSM because I will be traveling in the near future to Europe and I wanted to have service in Europe without taking on expensive roaming charges from my current wireless company.  I was a little worried when the phone arrived in a brown box inside of a plastic bag and a charger that did not resemble an Apple charger.  Well to my surprise the phone did not come with GSM Sim Card
column5: I called Verizon Wireless and they told me that they can ship me a Sim card the next day and I received it with my new number attached
column6: I placed the SIM card into the phone and then I  powered the phone on and made calls outgoing and incoming.  The phone was used/refurbished and it works great.  I have no complaints it is as if it was brand new....no complaints whatsoever.  I purchased this one for my child and I will be upgrading at a later date to buy an Unlocked GSM phone for myself as well....the price was great at $179.00 and all I did was add it to my existing plan for $20.00 a month with Verizon Wireless.  I would definitely recommend going this route if you want to avoid a costly phone for $600.00 or more and also avoid one and two year contracts with your wireless provider.  The phone only has 16gigs
column7: but again I purchased for my young child and now I can track them
column8: face-time them and call them when they are playing at their friends house.  its great and I am completely happy with it.  They have newer phones for a little bit more money
column9: but I'm happy with my purchase.  My only complaint is that it did not come with an Apple Earbud.  I have to purchase that separately.  Also the GSM phones do not come with SIM Cards
column10: you have to call your provider or go to the local store to have them assign one or send to your home."^5^February 5

^415655858^29^5^"So my son's dad (my boyfriend) and me both decided to purchase this phone as our upgrade on our Verizon plan. We both our Samsung lovers and both really enjoyed our new phone. column3: a stranger messages me on Facebook asking me if I knew whose phone this was.. I was completely astonished that after 5 days of the phone being washed away in the ocean
column4: coming back up onto the beach and surviving 5 days in 90 degree weather in the sand it still worked!! The person found me through Facebook from me messaging my boyfriend trying to get pics of the ocean not knowing it was washed away yet! So 5 stars to samsung for manufacturing the Galaxy S9 plus and 5 stars to the kind person who returned the phone!"^5^July 23

The case was destroyed and my phone was greasy but the rubber plugs on the case kept my ports protected and somehow right now I'm doing this review on my still amazingly working no problems phone. Definately a miracle but not completely coincidence. Please dont put phone in deep fryer to try out lol"^5^August 20

column2: ^415655858^10^5^"I have had the Galaxy S9 for 5 days now. For starters
column3: this is a great phone. It has a good display
column4: good camera
column5: and it is pretty good in low light compared to the Galaxy S6. But there have been tons of reviews that I've seen about the battery being bad. And I honestly don't think the battery is that bad. The battery has a little bit of a tough time when you are constantly using bigger apps all day long. But I don't think anyone in the reviews had been comparing the battery to an S6 that has been used for 3 years. Yesterday I unplugged the phone at about 7:30 am and had been pretty much constantly on it all day. I plugged the phone in about 12:30 am and it was around 25%. So it has a hard time being used all day. But today I unplugged it around 10:30 am. It is about 10:30 pm now
column6: so 12 hours
column7: and the phone is at 80%. Today I have been on YouTube and a few other apps for a small amount of time. Other than that it has just been sitting around. So the phone is really good at maintaining its battery while it is not in use too often. "^5^December 31

column1: ^908470140^27^6^"This is one amazing smartphone. Simply amazing in everyway. I've had this phone for the past 2 months and it has held up and performs like new. I can easily achieve a consistent 4-7 hours of constant use on heavy tasks such as gaming
column2: and media streaming. Of course
column3: this all depends on the way you actually use the device. It takes an average of 2 hours and 30 minutes to charge from around 5% to 100% with the included 5W Apple wall adapter and lightning cable. The Apple custom designed A9 chip with the M9 motion coprocessor delivers astonishing performance as it's the same exact chip-set from the iPhone 6s & 6s Plus. And get this
column4: the iPhone SE also outperforms those devices in benchmark scores thanks to the smaller lower resolution display which I don't mind. It's also paired with 2GB of RAM so multitasking and such is flawless. I can play AsphaltXtreme perfectly. And that's a very VERY demanding game. Social media such as Facebook
column5: Facebook Messenger
column6: Instagram
column7: and Snapchat run flawlessly. iOS 11.1.1 (which is the latest current public version of iOS as of now) runs very well. Although it can be better
column8: it's sufficient for my needs. We can all expect iOS 11 to be very much improved with iOS 11.2 in the near future. I come from budget Android devices and have been with them since late 2013
column9: and I must say iOS is honestly much better and smoother than any Android device I've ever used. Even against a Galaxy S5. And here's what's literally unbelievable
column10: the iPhone SE is selling for $129. Say whaaaaa??? Straight from Apple themselves unlocked it costs $350-$450. So as you can imagine this is an unbeatable deal. And the camera is a whole world of greatness. You can record full 4k @30FPS video. Although I prefer to record in 1080p @60 FPS as I like much smoother videos. Pictures are detailed and vibrant. It has excellent detailed low-light performance. The dual-flash on the rear is great. It delivers a balanced colored scene for your photos in low-light. All this is great and all except when you take a look at the FaceTime HD camera. It's a 1.2 megapixel sensor. So it won't blow your mind
column11: but it's still very good and very much tolerable. At least for me. It's capable of recording 720p @30fps video so while it's not amazing it's good. There's also the Retina Flash. Which in low-light flashes the display 3 times brighter than usual to illuminate your selfies. The display is very colorful and vibrant. And very detailed with a PPI of 326. Which essentially means if you hold it far enough away from your eyes
column12: you won't see any pixels. Even close up it looks great. Viewing angles are great. Nothing ground breaking just good as it is the same exact panel from the iPhone 5 and 5s. In fact they're literally interchangeable. Keep in mind that any and all cases/accessories from the 5 and 5s are supported on this device. Although
column13: with some iPhone 5 cases they cover the home button
column14: so those cases won't be able to be used with this device as you won't be able to use Touch ID with it. Speaking of Touch ID
column15: it's good. Again
column16: nothing amazing as it is the 1st Gen Touch ID. So it's fast and reliable
column17: just not as much as the newest 2nd Gen model. Speaker quality is good. Quite loud and distinguishable. It's mono but it's still good. Call quality is great. The Simple Mobile service coverage is good in my area. The build quality is amazing. Crafted from bead-blasted aluminum
column19: an inset stainless steel Apple logo
column20: and an all around precision crafted build
column21: you can and should expect nothing but amazement from this device. It's an absolutely beautiful smartphone. Sure the design as a whole is a bit dated and all but it's still classy and very much classic. It's also very light. Weighing in at 113 grams. It's quite small in my hand and it can very easily be used one handedly. You can also expect this device to last a long time as it should get software updates and will just be all around supported till around 2020ish. I do recommend a case to make this device last longer. Preferably a full body case such as an OtterBox Defender. Remember this is not a water-resistant smartphone. It's not indestructible. And it's not extremely durable. But it is the best thing for $129. So all in all
column22: I totally recommend this smartphone. It's literally a steal at this price!"^5^November 11

^180180421^32^0^"I received this item and it's in great condition. I believed this to be an unlocked iPhone 6 as stated. However
column3: when trying to activate the phone with my SIM card
column4: it kept telling me the SIM was not supported. I called my carrier and they said a new SIM card would resolve the issue. I purchased a new SIM card and got the same message
column5: it was not supported. I took the phone to my carrier's local agent and they tried three different SIM cards and were getting the same response. I was told to call Apple and they would be able to help me. I called Apple and after several minutes told me the phone was locked into AT&T and I would have to go to a store and have them unlock it. I drove to the nearest AT&T store (30 miles away) only to be told they couldn't do it at the store. They gave me the number for AT&T Customer Care and said they could unlock the phone for me. I drove the 30 miles back home and called. I was told to go to their website and request for the iPhone to be unlocked and the request could take up to 48 hours. I went to the website and put in the IMEI number and proceeded with my request to have the phone unlocked. At this time it directed me to a new screen stating the phone is unable to be unlocked at this time because all installment payments had not been paid. Needless to say
column6: I am beyond irate. I will be returning the iPhone and getting a refund."^1^May 10

^53126987^17^5^"My Samsung phone died with a few months left on the contract. I purchased this little GoPhone and put my AT&T SIM card inside and began using it as my phone. If you choose to go this route
column3: be aware that you will need to contact AT&T and provide proof of purchase and then they will activate the phone for you. I didn't know this and was initially frustrated because the phone didn't work but it was fine once activated.  It has most of the same features as a high end

column6: it only has about 3 GB of actual storage because of all the preloaded apps and the OS needs BUT it does come with the capability of adding storage with an SD card.  And
column7: it does not have the ability to block numbers but there is now an app for that. It is clearly modeled after the early generation iPhones but it isn't fooling anyone!  One caveat: be sure to install apps one at a time or transfer apps to the SD card one at a time to avoid issues with app use.  If your ability to install apps is compromised you will need to erase all apps and reset the phone. (Take it from me!)  Luckily
column8: it did not cause me to lose my photos. Speaking of photos
column9: the camera is simple to use and the photos are of decent quality. Again
column10: maybe not the best but definitely better than I expected."^5^September 9

Came back to the apple store a later day to find out it was a sprint phone and was told i should take it to sprint to get it unlocked. Drove to sprint to unlock it where they told me its not a sprint phone and it does not show up in their system and its an at&t phone. Sprint then told me i need to take it back to walmart to figure out what was wrong.

column1: After visiting numerous stores no one was able to figure out what the issue with the phone was and now i have a $600 paper weight."^1^April 20

column2: ^50132328^40^13^"Here are the concrete facts about the 'iPhone 6S 64GB refurbished' that I received
column3: ordered from this very page:

column1: 1. The outside sticker (and paper receipt in the box) has a gray/blue sticker on the outside shrink wrap that reads 'Apple iPhone 6s 64GB Space Gray LTE Cellular AT&T MKRG2LL/A'.
2. Once opened and inserting my carrier's SIM card to activate and setup the phone (in this case
column2: Ting)
column3: the setup stops at the a screen that says
column4: 'SIM card invalid'

column1: 3. After speaking with both Ting and AT&T
column2: and providing both with the phone's IMEI number
column3: it was discovered that the phone is LOCKED - AND - per AT&T's online Device Unlock Portal webpage - is currently active on another AT&T customer's account!

column1: 4. WAIT - THERE'S MORE! inside the box
column2: there is a double sided printed business card that has information regarding the phone's 90 day warranty policy. This is handled by 'Recon Group
column3: Inc'. It states if the product doesn't function
column4: etc... please complete the Warranty submission form located at 'www.The ReconGroup.com/Warranty'. Submitting the IMEI number
column5: the site comes back with 'We are sorry to inform you that this unit does not qualify for the warranty program because this units serial # or recon ID or IMEI is not registered in our database. Please contact the product manufacturer for further assistance.'

column1: Those are the cold facts on this phone
column2: folks.

column1: So to sum up - the phone I got is locked to AT&T and they will not unlock it - EVEN IF YOU WERE TO PUT THIS PHONE ON AT&T'S SERVICE. ALSO - the warranty company doesn't have the phone's IMEI on file and won't provide warranty service.

column2: your unlock request was denied because:Your device is currently active on another AT&T customer's account. '

column1: Would give it -5 stars if I could.

column2: ^50132328^28^2^"phone arrived initially locked to AT&T so it wouldn't recognize my t-mobile sim. i was ready to return it but thought of trying AT&T website to see if they have online unlocking procedure and they do
column3: even for non at&t customers. so i followed the procedure which is very simple and self explanatory and got an email with instruction to confirm the request within 24 hours. i confirmed it right away and approx 5 minutes later another email came in approving the request with instruction on how to go about the unlocking which is as simple as just inserting your sim card. anyway
column4: i was not expecting it would turn out this way because it's similar to the previous review except that mine has a better ending :)

column1: 4 stars overall because it's not readily unlocked. others would have simply returned it like my initial reaction.
5 stars for the phone. it's practically brand new with chargers and headset in seemingly unused condition. upon checking with apple warranty
column2: it has 6 months left.

column3: if you're going to buy one of these refurbished iPhones from Walmart.com
column4: make sure it is SOLD AND SHIPPED by Walmart.com. Pay attention to where it's coming from. You won't be sorry (unless you purchase from a third party on Walmart.com). The 5 Stars are for a phone sold and shipped by Walmart.

column2: I bought a refurbished iPhone 5S from Walmart.com. It arrived in mint condition
column3: in an Apple box
column4: with Apple accessories. Other than the slightly scuffed an smudged iPhone box
column5: the phone was utterly flawless. Had I not known myself that I had purchased a refurbished phone
column6: I would have thought it came straight from the Apple store brand new. It had a little note in the shipping box stating that it had been reconditioned and refurbished by 'The Recon Group.' I was very impressed
column7: so you can imagine why I came back to Walmart.com to look for another refurbished iPhone after my iPhone 5S was wearing out after two years of use.

column1: Thinking that all refurbished iPhones listed on Walmart.com would be the same type of experience
column2: I found the iPhone 6S I wanted and purchased with confidence. What I missed was that it was SOLD AND SHIPPED by JemJem.com--NOT Walmart.com. The phone arrived quickly
column3: but the experience paled in comparison to my first experience with a refurbished phone purchased on Walmart.com. The JemJem refurbished phone arrived in a lackluster box. It had a cheap aftermarket charger
column4: no earbuds
column5: no manuals or documentation
column6: and the phone itself looked like a used item. I was incredibly disappointed and decided to return the item to JemJem.

column2: I went back and looked at my iPhone 5S purchase history from two years ago. THAT phone was SOLD AND SHIPPED by Walmart.com (not JemJem or any other third party seller).

column1: I decided to try again and see if I could get an iPhone 6S that had been reconditioned and refurbished by 'The Recon Group'
column2: just like the initial 5S I had for two years. I was careful to choose a color and storage option that resulted in the phone being 'Sold & Shipped' by Walmart
column3: as seen in the screenshot with this review. I purchased it (at a lower price than the JemJem one
column4: actually) and waited with anticipation to see if it would be as delightful of an experience as I was hoping for. The phone arrived
column5: and it was PERFECT. It came with a note saying it was reconditioned by 'The Recon Group
column6: ' it had all Apple accessories
column7: and the experience was as delightful as my intitial experience with the iPhone 5S two years ago. I'm absolutely thrilled with the second try at a great refurbished iPhone 6S.

column1: Seems like the stock of those sold and shipped by Walmart come and go
column2: so if you can't find one one day then try again on another day. Watch it. Be patient. You'll be happy with your purchase."^5^March 3

we went to Verizon to activate the two phones and one of the phones did not work with the carrier as advertised (perhaps the phone was stolen?). So it's essentially useless. I tried calling and emailing the vendor but received no response.

column1: Between sending incompatible chargers with the iPhones and sending a phone that was falsely advertised as working with Verizon
column2: I am surprised Smart Mobile is able to partner with a largely reputable company like Walmart.

column1: I will never purchase a phone from them again. Buyer beware."^1^January 4

column2: ^43241911^9^11^"Bad ESN/IMEI ! I called Verizon to set up service for the iphone

I called the Recon Group which is the company that refurbishes phones and other electronics for Walmart. They could not get the phone out of contract with Verizon and told me to return the phone and order a replacement. This was going to be a Christmas gift for me daughter and I needed it by December 24. Given the time crunch
column4: I drove 30 minutes to the nearest Walmart. Thankfully

column6: but now they were out of stock!!! This was an overall horrible experience purchasing a refurbished phone from the Recon Group."^1^December 21

^49053770^120^12^"My daughter purchased a 'certified refurbished' I Phone through this company. The phone arrived in a bubble wrap envelope without any paperwork or receipt. AT this point I decided to contact the company. They are more than willing to accept a return with a 20% restocking fee and without paying for return shipping and will refund her money (less the 20%) if they determine the phone is indeed defective and they they believe it is not her fault (which will take time- as in weeks). When all is said and done it will be easier to have the Apple store repair the phone. Either way she will be out extra money but at least then we will know she has a properly working product. ^49053770^17^5^"Very bad online shopping experience. Would never recommend anything from Quick Wireless EVER. Bottom line is the 'Refurbished Apple iPhone 5s 16 GB Smartphone (Unlocked)' phone didn't work with my carrier -- Cricket. They charged insisted on charging me a 20% of item total restocking fee as well.

column1: Here are my notes (with dates) that I kept to keep track of this lengthy
column2: annoying
column3: and costly process:

column1: 6/1 Ordered the iPhone 5s 16 GB unlocked gray smartphone via Walmart.com for $99.99 (plus tax)

column2: but doesn't work on my network. The lady at the Cricket wireless store said she'd seen several phones ordered via walmart.com that wouldn't work as claimed.

column1: 6/7 Called Quick Wireless directly and spoke with woman who said they can only refund
column2: not exchange items. She went on to say to avoid a 20% restocking fee
column3: I need to write a note saying phone did not work on network is being returned. Said she would immediately send two emails:

column1: I did not receive any emails.

6/8 Messaged Quick Wireless via Walmart.com requesting those emails. I promptly received those emails and an additional email from Quick Wireless justifying themselves saying they did indeed send the previous emails.
6/13 Mailed iPhone back to Quick Wireless with note inside about not working
6/15 Phone delivered to Quick Wireless per USPS tracking website
6/19 Contacted Quick Wireless via Walmart.com asking remaining amount be refunded as well. They replied saying they have submitted my dispute against the restocking fee.
6/20 Received an email back saying 'The unit was reevaluated and that we found it to be functional therefore we stand firm in our decision regarding the restocking fee.

Buyer beware! I should've listened to the other reviews and the overall low score. I don't know why Walmart doesn't scrutinize their vendors more thoroughly or can any yahoo sell some merchandise they have?
